intro: Smithia uniflora, commonly known as the single-flower smithia, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and small, clustered white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cold, high-altitude environments. Its leaves are pinnately divided, and it produces small, oval-shaped fruits that contain a single seed. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Smithia uniflora is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
